content.title: Venous Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Paget-Schroetter)
content.description: Effort-related thrombosis of the subclavian-axillary vein due to compression at the thoracic outlet, classically occurring in young athletic individuals.
content.epidemiology: Young adults (20-40), male predominance, associated with repetitive overhead activities (swimming, throwing, weightlifting)
content.pathophysiology: Compression of subclavian vein between first rib and clavicle leads to intimal injury and thrombosis. Extrinsic compression from scalene muscles, costoclavicular ligament, or subclavius muscle.

diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: First-line, shows thrombus and flow abnormality
diagnosis.venography: Gold standard, shows extent and collaterals

treatment_algorithm.acute: Catheter-directed thrombolysis within 2 weeks of symptom onset
treatment_algorithm.surgical: First rib resection (transaxillary or supraclavicular approach)
treatment_algorithm.timing: Rib resection 2-4 weeks after thrombolysis, followed by venoplasty

content.statement: Venous Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Paget-Schroetter) is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Thoracic-Outlet that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Venous Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Paget-Schroetter) helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Venous Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Paget-Schroetter) include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Venous Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Paget-Schroetter).
